document.title: Splitting the Cartesian Hair
document.abstract: The "Believing Game," at its deepest level, protects a space where students and teacher can contemplatively ponder what they will choose to love.

field.value: Mary Rose Oâ€™Reilley is the author of The Love of Impermanent Things: A Threshold Ecology and The Barn at the End of the World: The Apprenticeship of a Quaker, Buddhist Shepherd (Milkweed Editions). Her first book of poetry, Half Wild (Louisiana State University) won the 2005 Walt Whitman Award of the Academy of American Poets, judged by Mary Oliver. Her books about teaching include The Peaceable Classroom, Radical Presence and The Garden at Night: Burnout and Breakdown in the Teaching Life (Heinemann). Retired from university teaching, she works at being a gardener, potter, and folk musician.
